--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> On Tue, 24 Aug 2004 23:04:49 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
> <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> > Those are really nice initial results.  It seems like this is a
> > promising research direction.  Some things I'm wondering...How 
many
> > generations does it take to get the "A" discriminator eye?  
> 
> We've been trying a bunch of ad hoc experiments, with all sorts of
> parameters, so it's difficult to generalize at this point.  But in 
the
> more successful runs, we usually reach 85-95% fitness within around
> 100 generations, and it normally plateaus out from there.  We've 
done
> up to 500 generations, but we've seen little improvement past the
> first 100 or so.
> 

Given you get such a high performance after 100 generations that may 
make sense that things level out, but once you find some parameters 
that you are comfortable with, it might be interesting to do a 
single weeklong run or something like that to see if things improve 
slowly over thousands of generations.  We have seen that happen in 
some of our experiments.  Sometimes there can be over 1,000 
generations and then a sudden stream of improvements.   I think it's 
because sufficient complexity builds up to support an elaborated 
strategy, so it's possible that wouldn't happen in blended runs if 
they don't build up complexity during stagnation, but the main point 
is that thousands of generations is a whole other time scale that is 
worth checking out if it's possible.  Of course it's totally 
possible nothing will happen.

ken
